text: My opinion on it has varied over time. Like, I think, most people, I railed against it at first and tried to think through lots of different ways of churning to reduce the amount paid. In the end I accepted it and realised my time was better spent looking for other profitable strategies rather than coming up with PC reduction strategies. But coming to this way of thinking took a long time. A productive way to think about it is an R&D credit for trying out new things. It's like a (big) rebate on your losses if you try something new that isn't profitable. Having said all of that, I am very recently starting to think again about strategies for reducing it. That's only because I've been exposed to some fresh ideas in 2024 that I think shift the calculus enough for it to be worth spending time on. But I retain the self awareness that as tempting as it might be to reduce PC, there's almost certainly better ways to spend my time

It's like a (big) rebate on your losses if you try something new that isn't profitable. Having said all of that, I am very recently starting to think again about strategies for reducing it. But I retain the self awareness that as tempting as it might be to reduce PC, there's almost certainly better ways to spend my time

text:
Similar humble start <@UUE6E1LA1>, my old man always used to say he wanted to be the guy who paid the most tax. Took me a while to understand that. 

PC seems bad but compared to almost anything else that's legal we have mercifully low fixed overheads. No buildings, no wages, no accountant, no insurance, no stock etc etc. Throw in complete freedom about when and how hard to work..... Most would kill for the deal we get. If people don't like it, they should try a proper job and see how that goes.

If people don't like it, they should try a proper job and see how that goes.

text: Yeah I know we've got a good thing - too good you might say as here in UK it's all tax free too. Still no harm in doing things to reduce it or make more profit to counter the effects.

elements.text: Yeah I know we've got a good thing - too good you might say as here in UK it's all tax free too. Still no harm in doing things to reduce it or make more profit to counter the effects.

text: V true <@UUE6E1LA1>.   I generate about 35% a week and had big losses pre 2010.  It means I swerve PC so it's easy to preach when I get away scot-free. But generally if I wanted to earn more I'd try to earn more rather than look for savings, advice I was given years ago.

elements.text: V true

text: Yeah seems to be the concensus.  My lifetime commission was just over 25% when I hit threshold so I was way off the 40% needed to avoid it.

text: I'm generating about 35% a week because my edge is pathetic :joy:, and my lifetime head start came at a heavy price:thinking_face:.  The easiest way to reduce your pc is to stop being so good.

elements.text: I'm generating about 35% a week because my edge is pathetic
, and my lifetime head start came at a heavy price
.  The easiest way to reduce your pc is to stop being so good.

text: I kind of inferred that you get to view the PC tab on your account once you cross 50K gross P&L (at least that was the first time I noticed it appear on the website). At that point I was 49% commission. The week prior to getting the first PC deduction it was actually 22% (not 25%). I've not calculated it but from memory my weekly commission is anything between 5 and 12% on profitable weeks. I found the whole PC thing very confusing as they add an artificial chunk of PC charges that you've never actually paid to that page now just to make it up to 40%. I've never used the account statement operations in the API but now I've got these payments coming out I should get on that so I can track what PC has gone out so I can keep control of ACTUAL profit rather than what the P&L page and settled orders operations give you.

elements.text: I kind of inferred that you get to view the PC tab on your account once you cross 50K gross P&L (at least that was the first time I noticed it appear on the website). I've never used the account statement operations in the API but now I've got these payments coming out I should get on that so I can track what PC has gone out so I can keep control of ACTUAL profit rather than what the P&L page and settled orders operations give you.

text: So if nothing else, I should probably be looking to generate some extra commission to prevent moving up to the 50% bracket in the future (assuming that lifetime commission rate reduction trend continues). Don't think I'll ever be getting near the 60% level with current strategies.

text: I'm not saying there's anything wrong with it, presumably there're people making money like that and I think <@U4H19D1D2> lays at long prices a bit, I just don't fancy the money management. More recently I've got a bit more into laying at longer prices but I rarely go beyond 200 and then not for much. Risking that much at that price seems like a real adverse selection trap.
